briefing.title: Custom Kernels for All from Codex and Claude
briefing.note: A new tool release around Custom Kernels targets gaps in current developer workflows. Why it matters: Custom Kernels is worth evaluating if your current tools are hitting limits.

briefing.title: ClawRouter
briefing.note: Growing traction for ClawRouter on GitHub suggests rising builder interest. Why it matters: Community interest in ClawRouter is growing — check repo health before committing.

briefing.title: Exa AI Introduces Exa Instant: A Sub-200ms Neural Search Engine Designed to Eliminate Bottlenecks for Real-Time Agentic Workflows
briefing.note: New tutorial content on Exa Instant walks through a practical implementation. Why it matters: The Exa Instant development is a useful signal for teams shipping AI products.

editors_note.headline: This week
editors_note.thesis: This week's signal is clear: business model decisions are moving faster than product roadmaps. If you're not tracking Introducing Lockdown Mode and Elevated Risk labels in, you're already behind.
editors_note.hook: The headline drives the week, but the real question is what it means for your vendor assumptions and Q2 plans.
editors_note.spotlight: The lead story is the most likely to change near-term decisions for teams shipping AI products.
editors_note.underhyped: Custom Kernels for All from Codex and Claude deserves more attention than it's getting.
editors_note.risk: Vendor and pricing risk is elevated this week — review your dependency list.

lead_story.title: Introducing Lockdown Mode and Elevated Risk labels in ChatGPT
lead_story.what_happened: Lockdown Mode just shipped; we're adding it to the list of options to benchmark this quarter.
lead_story.our_take: Treat Lockdown Mode as a planning input — the second-order effects matter more than the headline.
lead_story.what_to_do: Bring Lockdown Mode to your next planning sync — it may affect Q2 priorities.

sections.title: Industry Radar
sections.deck: The moves that change product plans, budgets, and positioning.

articles.title: Why top talent is walking away from OpenAI and xAI
articles.summary: The OpenAI news is worth a closer look for teams making near-term tool or vendor calls (via TechCrunch AI).
articles.what_happened: The OpenAI development has implications for vendor strategy and competitive positioning.
articles.why_it_matters: The OpenAI shift affects competitive positioning — factor it into Q2 planning.
articles.what_to_do: Add OpenAI as a discussion item in your next strategy or planning meeting.
articles.our_take: Teams that factor OpenAI into next quarter early usually gain execution room later.

articles.title: OpenAI sidesteps Nvidia with unusually fast coding model on plate-sized chips
articles.summary: The OpenAI news is worth a closer look for teams making near-term tool or vendor calls (via Ars Technica AI).
articles.what_happened: Industry activity around OpenAI may shift competitive dynamics this quarter.
articles.why_it_matters: Industry changes involving OpenAI are likely to affect near-term planning cycles.
articles.what_to_do: Monitor OpenAI for follow-on product or pricing changes over the next month.
articles.our_take: Strategic positioning around OpenAI is shifting faster than most roadmap cycles account for.

sections.title: Builder's Bench
sections.deck: New tooling worth evaluating in an actual workflow this week.

articles.title: On Agent Frameworks and Agent Observability
articles.summary: The On Agent Frameworks paper offers techniques that applied teams should track for downstream impact (via LangChain Blog).
articles.what_happened: On Agent Frameworks adds a new option to the builder toolkit — worth a scoped evaluation.
articles.why_it_matters: The open release of On Agent Frameworks adds a viable alternative to proprietary options.
articles.what_to_do: Try On Agent Frameworks on your most common use case — measure the gap vs your current setup.
articles.our_take: Evaluate the docs and community, not just the feature list. That's what determines staying power.

articles.title: Show HN: I'm 75, building an OSS Virtual Protest Protocol for digital activism
articles.summary: Keep Show HN on your radar — it could affect planning or tooling decisions soon (via Hacker News).
articles.what_happened: A new tool release around Show HN targets gaps in current developer workflows.
articles.why_it_matters: The Show HN release addresses gaps that many builder teams have flagged.
articles.what_to_do: Try Show HN on a non-critical task this week and log the results.
articles.our_take: Don't adopt tools based on hype. Run it against your ugliest edge case first.

articles.title: ClawRouter
articles.summary: The agent-native LLM router powering OpenClaw — by BlockRun. Currently at 2,405 stars with ~240 stars/day growth.
articles.what_happened: Growing traction for ClawRouter on GitHub suggests rising builder interest.
articles.why_it_matters: Community interest in ClawRouter is growing — check repo health before committing.
articles.what_to_do: Check ClawRouter for recent activity, open issues, and license compatibility this week.
articles.our_take: Popularity and production-readiness are different things. Check the last commit date and open issues first.

prompt_of_the_week.text: Compare these two technical approaches for [problem]. Give me a decision matrix with columns for: complexity, maintainability, performance, and team skill requirements.
prompt_of_the_week.tip: Describe both approaches briefly. Include your team size and deployment constraints.
